Well yeah, but that also makes it easy to forget that we’re still writing CSS. We can get caught up in all the new tools and tricks that Sass lets us do so easily that we lose sight of some CSS that might not be as awesome as we think it is.</p> </div> </div> </div> </li> <li class="post-teaser--li"><div class="post-teaser "> <div class="post-teaser--text"> <h2 class="post-teaser--title"><a href="#" class="post-teaser--link">Fixing H&amp;FJ Font Previews</a></h2> <div class="post-teaser--excerpt"> <p>I&#39;m considering Hoefler &amp; Frere-Jones webfonts for a new project. The service looks great but I haven&#39;t signed up yet. This may be different once I&#39;ve paid for something, but for now their web preview kind of sucks. (sorry H&amp;FJ) I want to test my own text before making such a big commitment but they only show their own promo text.</p> </div> </div> <div class="post-teaser--thumb"> <a href="#" class="post-teaser--image-link"> <img src="https:&#x2F;&#x2F;unsplash.it&#x2F;800&#x2F;800&#x2F;?image&#x3D;500" alt="Square Thumbnail"/> </a> </div> </div> </li> </ul> </section>
